newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Turkey negotiating to buy Belgian, Dutch missiles.
newsitem.headline: Turkey negotiating to buy Belgian, Dutch missiles.

text.p: The Belgian Defence Ministry confirmed on Monday media reports that French defence company Thomson-CSF was negotiating the sale to Turkey of surplus Belgian and Dutch surface-to-air missile systems.
"Talks are underway. We cannot talk yet about a sale," spokesman Colonel Ronny Van den Broule told Reuters.

Thomson-CSF was seeking to acquire the missiles from Belgium and the Netherlands before selling them on to Turkey. The Belgian Defence Ministry was not in direct talks with Turkey, Van den Broule said.

The talks coincide with renewed tension between Turkey and Greece over the divided Mediterranean island of Cyprus where the Greek Cypriot government in the southern half plans to deploy S-300 anti-aircraft missiles bought from Russia.
The Belgian Foreign Ministry, which would have to approve the export of missiles to Turkey, said it was too early to say if the dispute could obstruct a deal with Thomson-CSF.

"There's no political decision for the time being and (no procedure) has started," spokesman Andre Querton told Reuters. "At a certain moment, if a deal goes through financially, it will have to be put to the...foreign and trade ministers. Only then would a foreign policy review start."
The Dutch foreign and defence ministries declined to comment.
Belgium is selling the U.S. Raytheon-made HAWK missile systems as part of major cutbacks to its armed forces and a freeze on new defence spending.
The defence ministry spokesman noted that as well as requiring domestic approval, any sale would also have to be cleared by the U.S.

Belgium has previously sold other surplus defence equipment through commercial intermediaries. In 1995 Belgian defence firm Sabca refitted and sold to Chile 20 Mirage jet fighters it bought from the air force.
